column3: officially the Principality of Andorra (Catalan: Principat d'Andorra)
column4: also called the Principality of the Valleys of Andorra (Catalan: Principat de les Valls d'Andorra)
column5: is a sovereign landlocked microstate in Southwestern Europe
column6: located in the eastern Pyrenees mountains and bordered by Spain and France. Created under a charter in A.D. 988
column7: the present Principality was formed in A.D. 1278. It is known as a principality as it is a monarchy headed by two Co-Princes – the Spanish/Roman Catholic Bishop of Urgell and the President of France. Andorra is the sixth-smallest nation in Europe
column8: having an area of 468 km2 (181 sq mi) and a population of approximately 85
column9: 000. Its capital Andorra la Vella is the highest capital city in Europe

column1: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Catalan_language	"Catalan (/ˈkætəlæn/; autonym: català [kətəˈla] [kataˈla]) is a Romance language named for its origins in Catalonia
column2: in what is northeastern Spain and adjoining parts of France. It is the national and only official language of Andorra
column3: and a co-official language of the Spanish autonomous communities of Catalonia
column5: and Valencia (where the language is known as Valencian
column6: and there exist regional standards). It also has semi-official status in the city of Alghero on the Italian island of Sardinia. It is also spoken with no official recognition in parts of the Spanish autonomous communities of Aragon (La Franja) and Murcia (Carche)
column7: and in the historic French region of Roussillon/Northern Catalonia
column8: roughly equivalent to the department of Pyrénées-Orientales. According to the Statistical Institute of Catalonia in 2008 the Catalan language is the second most commonly used in Catalonia
column10: as a native or self-defining language. The Generalitat of Catalunya spends part of its annual budget on the promotion of the use of Catalan in Catalonia and in other territories. Catalan evolved from Vulgar Latin around the eastern Pyrenees in the 9th century. During the Low Middle Ages it saw a golden age as the literary and dominant language of the Crown of Aragon
column11: and was widely used all over the Mediterranean. The union of Aragon with the other territories of Spain in 1479 marked the start of the decline of the language. In 1659 Spain ceded Northern Catalonia to France
column12: and Catalan was banned in both states in the early 18th century. 19th-century Spain saw a Catalan literary revival
column13: which culminated in the 1913 orthographic standardization
column14: and the officialization of the language during the Second Spanish Republic (1931–39). However
column15: the Francoist dictatorship (1939–75) banned the language again. Since the Spanish transition to democracy (1975–1982)
column16: Catalan has been recognized as an official language
column19: all of which have contributed to its increased prestige. There is no parallel in Europe of such a large
column21: non-state speech community. Catalan dialects are relatively uniform
column22: and are mutually intelligible. They are divided into two blocks
column24: differing mostly in pronunciation. The terms ""Catalan"" and ""Valencian"" (respectively used in Catalonia and the Valencian Community) are two different varieties of the same language. There are two institutions regulating the two standard varieties
column25: the Institute of Catalan Studies in Catalonia and the Valencian Academy of the Language in Valencia. Catalan shares many traits with its neighboring Romance languages. However
column26: despite being mostly situated in the Iberian Peninsula
column27: Catalan differs more from Iberian Romance (such as Spanish and Portuguese) in terms of vocabulary

column38: and can be combined in very complex ways. Verbs are split in several paradigms and are inflected for person
